text.intro:
Neutrality and transparency are important to us.

We work to make data more visible, more clear, more understandable and more comparable. To this end, we bring our own research together with data from various sources, accompanied by editorials which we try to make as comprehensible as possible.
text.sources:
The general company profile information (Name, legal form, address, structure, revenue...) is based on datasets from North Data, Brex and OpenCorporates.

The information about data privacy for selected companies is the result of research done by the polypoly Cooperative. This is based among other sources on the privacy policies of the companies German websites. These do not represent all the data that a company collects or shares, but only the data behaviour that we could research.
text.research.first:
Our research is focused on the impact data privacy behaviour has on the individual user. Here we try to find and visualise information that is usually invisible or hard to get to and understand. When we research privacy policies and data behavior for example we are usually looking for the following:

  • What data is gathered
  • What data is shared
  • Who are the companies data is shared with
  • What is the purpose/reason given for sharing that data
text.research.second:
Often concrete information is missing or misleading. No two privacy policies are alike and very few share any structural similarity. Since the introduction of the GDPR, there have been some improvements, but we still need to do a fair amount of decoding.

We also do a good amount of context research to help us better understand what the impact of sharing individual data types could be, what certain companies or industries are doing with user data, or what impacts might be expected from sharing across jurisdictions.

Our research is an ongoing process that keeps being improved, similarly we regularly update our database. This research is also informed by the work of others in the field e.g. from North Data or independent researchers.

For the current version of polyExplorer we selected 5 companies and present them as "featured". This selection does not indicate any judgment on those companies. We simply spent more time researching them than we did others. The selection and number of featured companies will grow over time.
text.validation: We are a young company with few people and grand ambitions. For now we validate our data according to the four eyes principle, meaning data and correlations are always checked by at least two people from our research team.
text.aggregation:
We work on making data clear and understandable. This means that we build correlations between datasets, and also aggregate data to make it more accessible and comparable.

To get from a Privacy Policy document that is often vague and uses a lot of open language to a clear and comparable representation of data flows can be challenging.

Over the course of interpreting vague and indefinite language, our researchers have tried to be as specific as can be where possible, but making sure they don't read more into a text than is there. Regarding ambiguous statements in privacy policies, we have aimed to use the W3C Data Privacy Vocabulary (in short: DPV) to the appropriate level of granularity. For example, when a vague statement could be referring to a number of datatypes, we chose the DPV term that covers the possibilities more generally.
text.presentation: Our approach is to explain and explore data in our data driven stories and features. We will guide you if wanted and needed. And we will allow you to explore more deeply and comprehensively as well.
